title: 113_hr1653
content:
The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The Pro Football Hall of Fame's mission is to honor individuals who have made outstanding contributions to professional football, preserve historic documents and artifacts, educate the public about the sport's origin and growth, and promote its positive values. The Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963, enshrining a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors, including legends like Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, established in 1963, has inducted 273 members including iconic figures like Hutson, Bronko Nagurski, and Jim Thorpe. The Hall of Fame features a bronze bust, gold jacket, and ring as symbols of membership. The museum has seen nearly 9,000,000 visitors and houses the world's largest collection on professional football, with over 20,000 three-dimensional artifacts. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has a vast collection of over 20,000 three-dimensional artifacts and 20,000,000 pages of documents, including 3,000,000 photographic images. It reaches a worldwide audience of nearly 15,000,000 people annually through various channels such as visitors to the museum, events, website, and educational programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, minted to half-dollar specifications in title 31, United States Code. The coins minted under this Act will have designs emblematic of professional football, with inscriptions including the year "2017" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2017.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. Surcharges received are promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame is subject to audit requirements for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to ensure that the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year does not exceed the annual limitation set by section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
